newsitem.title: ROMANIA: EU loans for Romania tied to IMF accord - Santer.
newsitem.headline: EU loans for Romania tied to IMF accord - Santer.

text.p: European Commission President Jacques Santer on Thursday linked resumed EU loans for Romania's balance of payments problems to approval by the IMF board of a new loan package for the ex-communist country.

"A first tranche of European Union aid worth 40 million Ecus ($53.6 million) for Romania's balance of payments will be released as soon as the IMF board approves the new deal with Romania at the end of April," Santer told a news conference.
Bucharest is seeking up to $400 million in new loans from the International Monetary Fund, to support reforms, including faster privatisation and restructuring of state industries.
Santer said the EU would release a second tranche of credits by the end of June, contingent on implementation of reforms by the new centrist coalition government.
International lending institutions suspended loans because the former leftist administration failed keep reform pledges.
Romania has promised to cut to $1.4 billion last year's current account deficit of $2.3 billion.
Santer also said the EU was adding 30 million Ecus to its $330 million PHARE assistance programme. Romania has signed an association deal with the EU and hopes to join after the year 2,000.
